H0.text: What would Kevin Scale have been called if it had adopted the originator's first name. Kelvin Scale

H1.text: What would Kevin Scale have been called if it had adopted the originator's first name. Thomson Scale

H2.text: What would Kevin Scale have been called if it had adopted the originator's first name. Lord Scale

H3.text: What would Kevin Scale have been called if it had adopted the originator's first name. William Scale

A4.text: The 19th century British scientist Lord Kelvin first developed and proposed the scale.

A5.text: William Thomson published a paper on an absolute thermometric scale in October 1848.

A6.text: William Thomson published a paper on the dynamical theory of heat with numerical results deduced from Mr Joule's equivalent of a thermal unit, and M. Regnault's observations on steam in March 1851.

A7.text: The scale was named after Lord Kelvin, not William Thomson.

A8.text: He invented the current balance, also known as the Kelvin balance or Ampere balance (SiC), for the precise specification of the ampere, the standard unit of electric current.
